title: Lesson 18: Cell Specialisation and Tissues
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding the relationship between cell structure and function in specialised cells, and how cells group to form tissues. Bridge to Module 2.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the relationship between cell structure and function in specialised cells (red blood cell, nerve cell, xylem vessel, muscle cell).
Students can explain how specialisation results from differential gene expression leading to different organelle complements.
Students can identify how specialised cells group to form tissues (introduction to Module 2).

syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: IQ1: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: I can match specialised cell types to their specific adaptations.
I can explain why a muscle cell has many mitochondria while a skin cell has less.
I can define 'tissue' as a group of similar cells working together.

engagementHook.title: The Specialist Workforce
engagementHook.content: 'Your body has 200+ cell types, each shaped perfectly for one job. Flattened discs for gas exchange, long wires for electrical signals, hollow pipes for water transport. How does a generic stem cell become these specialists? And how do they team up? Today we meet the cellular specialists.'

keyConcepts.definition: Cell shape and organelle composition match the job.
No nucleus (more room for haemoglobin), biconcave disc (increases surface area for gas exchange).
Long axons (transmit signals), many mitochondria (energy for ion pumps), specialized membrane with channels.
Elongated, contain actin/myosin (microfilaments from Lesson 8), many mitochondria, can be multinucleated.
Dead at maturity (no cytoplasm), thickened walls (lignin), hollow tubes for water transport.
Groups of similar specialised cells working together (epithelial, connective, muscle, nervous—preview only, detailed in Module 2).

misconceptions.correction: Dramatic variation in shape and organelle content.

misconceptions.misconception: Red blood cells have no DNA because they don't need it
misconceptions.correction: They lose nucleus during maturation to make room for haemoglobin—this limits their lifespan (120 days).
They are dead at functional maturity (only cell walls remain as pipes).

items: More haemoglobin, increased surface area for O₂/CO₂ exchange
Contraction/movement, high ATP for sustained activity

contentSections.title: Organelle Abundance in Specialised Cells
contentSections.content: Three cells side by side: Muscle cell (packed with mitochondria), Pancreatic cell (packed with RER/Golgi), Leaf mesophyll cell (packed with chloroplasts).
keyPoints: Differentiation changes organelle numbers to suit function
contentSections.example: Athletes have more mitochondria in muscle cells due to training (adaptation).

contentSections.title: From Cells to Tissues
contentSections.content: Specialised cells of the same type group together forming tissues (e.g., muscle tissue, nervous tissue). Connects to Module 2 (Organisation of Living Things: cells → tissues → organs → systems).
contentSections.example: Epithelial tissue lines lungs (gas exchange) and intestines (absorption)—different specialisations, same tissue type.

multipleChoice.question: Which adaptation increases the surface area of red blood cells for gas exchange?
multipleChoice.rationale: RBC structure. Biconcave shape maximises surface area for gas exchange.

multipleChoice.question: A cell specialised for secreting large amounts of protein would be expected to have abundant:
options: Rough endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Rough endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus
multipleChoice.rationale: Secretory pathway organelles. RER for synthesis, Golgi for packaging.

multipleChoice.question: Xylem vessels are able to transport water efficiently because they:
options: Are alive and actively pump water
Are dead at maturity and hollow
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Are dead at maturity and hollow
multipleChoice.rationale: Xylem specialisation. Dead cells form hollow tubes with no cytoplasm to impede flow.

shortAnswer.question: Explain how the structure of a red blood cell is adapted for its function in gas transport. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Biconcave shape provides large surface area (relative to volume) for gas exchange/diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide
1 mark: Absence of nucleus/most organelles allows more room for haemoglobin (the oxygen-carrying molecule)
shortAnswer.commonError: Mentioning mitochondria for energy (RBCs have none).

shortAnswer.question: Compare the organelle composition of a pancreatic cell (which secretes digestive enzymes) with a skin cell, with reference to the endomembrane system. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Pancreatic cells have abundant rough ER and Golgi apparatus (for protein synthesis and packaging) compared to skin cells
1 mark: This reflects their specialised function of secreting proteins/enzymes versus the protective function of skin cells (or reference to secretory pathway)
shortAnswer.commonError: Stating skin cells have no RER (they have some, just less).

definitions: Specialised cells have specific adaptations (shape, organelles) for their function.
Red blood cells: Biconcave, no nucleus, maximise gas exchange.
Muscle cells: Many mitochondria, contractile proteins.
Nerve cells: Long extensions for signalling.
Xylem: Dead, hollow tubes for water transport.
Tissues = groups of specialised cells working together (bridge to Module 2).
keyPoints: Structure matches function in all specialised cells
RBC: biconcave + no nucleus = maximum gas exchange
diagrams: Organelle abundance in different cell types

shortAnswer: The red blood cell has a biconcave disc shape, which provides a large surface area relative to its volume. This shape maximises the surface area available for gas exchange, allowing efficient diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide across the cell membrane. Additionally, mature red blood cells lack a nucleus and most other organelles, which creates more space inside the cell for haemoglobin molecules, the protein that carries oxygen. This adaptation maximises the oxygen-carrying capacity of each cell.

Pancreatic cells that secrete digestive enzymes have abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus compared to skin cells. The rough ER is essential for synthesising the large quantities of protein enzymes that pancreatic cells produce. The Golgi apparatus is then responsible for modifying, packaging, and sorting these enzymes for secretion. This high abundance of secretory pathway organelles reflects the pancreatic cell's specialised function of producing and exporting proteins, whereas skin cells primarily serve a protective function and therefore do not require such extensive protein synthesis and secretion machinery.
